summary: Decades of nuclear energy research and weapons development created radioactive waste at sites in the Midwest and Northeast U.S.—leading to environmental risks for nearby communities. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is cleaning up 19 sites at an estimated cost of $2.6 billion. But the Corps isn't using opportunities to manage this work in a coordinated centralized way. The Corps could use its resources more...
title: Nuclear Waste Cleanup: Army Corps Could Benefit from Following Leading Practices for Program Management for Contaminated Sites
